column1: == History ==
The area of Surat Thani was already inhabited in prehistoric times by Semang and Malayan tribes. Founded in the 3rd century
column2: the Srivijaya kingdom dominated the Malay Peninsula until the 13th century. The city of Chaiya contains ruins from the Srivijaya period
column3: and it was probably a regional capital of the kingdom. Some Thai historians even argue that it was the kingdom's capital for a time
column4: but this is disputed. Wiang Sa was another important settlement of the time.

column1: After the fall of the Srivijaya
column2: the area was divided into the cities (mueang) of Chaiya
column4: and Khirirat Nikhom. Chaiya was administered directly from the Thai capital
column5: while Thatong and Khirirat were controlled by the Nakhon Si Thammarat Kingdom. In 1899
column6: they were all merged into a single province called Chaiya. In 1915
column7: the court of the Monthon Chumphon was transferred  to Bandon
column8: which received the new name of Surat Thani on 29 July 1915
column9: during a visit of King Vajiravudh (Rama VI). This was likely influenced by the major port city of Surat in Gujarat
column10: India. The monthon was also renamed Surat. In 1926 it was abolished and incorporated into monthon Nakhon Si Thammarat. The monthon was dissolved in 1933
column11: and the province became a first level administrative subdivision.

column1: The provincial administration was in a building in Tha Kham (Phunphin District). Shortly before World War II
column2: it was moved to the city of Surat Thani
column3: on the banks of the Tapi River
column4: which is named after the Tapi River in southern Gujarat
column5: India. When the Japanese invaded Thailand on 8 December 1941
column6: the administrative building was destroyed during the battle for the city. It was rebuilt in 1954
column8: a bomb planted by communist rebels blew up the building
column9: killing five people. The third and present building was relocated to the south of the city
column10: and the former site of the provincial hall is now the site of the city pillar shrine (Lak Mueang).

column1: The main agricultural products of the province are coconut and rambutan. The coconuts are often picked from the tree by specially trained monkeys
column2: mostly pig-tailed macaques (Macaca nemestrina). The monkey school of the late Somporn Saekhow is the most known training centre. Rambutan trees were first planted in Surat Thani in 1926 by the Chinese Malay Mr. K. Vong in Ban Na San District. An annual rambutan fair is held in early-August and includes a parade of highly decorated floats on the Tapi River. Rubber tree plantations are also common in the province.

column1: A notable local product is the hand-woven silk cloth from the coastal village Phum Riang in Chaiya District. Chaiya is also the most famous source of red eggs
column2: a local specialty. Ducks are fed with crabs and fish and the eggs are then preserved by placing them in a soil-salt mixture.

column1: Tourism is the major source of provincial income. The province earned 64 billion baht from tourism in 2018. That revenue accounted for 63 percent of Surat Thani's overall tourism income

column1: == Health ==
The main and largest hospital of Surat Thani is Surat Thani Hospital
column2: a regional hospital operated by the Ministry of Public Health (MOPH). MOPH also operates a general hospital in Ko Samui and a community hospital in each the 17 other districts of the province.

column1: == National parks ==
Mu Ko Ang Thong National Park is a marine national park in the Gulf of Thailand. It covers 42 islands in a total area of 102 km2
column2: of which about 50 km2 are land and the rest is water. The park was established on 12 November 1980. The northern tip of Ko Phaluai is also part of the marine park. There is a ranger station
column5: and a restaurant at Ao Phi Beach on Ko Wua Talap.

column1: Khao Sok National Park is the largest area of virgin forest in southern Thailand and is a remnant of rain forest which is older and more diverse than the Amazon rain forest.
